pullRequest.body:
A tool for library-scale analysis of unused imports.

`lake exe unused module_1 module_2 ... module_n`

will generate a markdown table with rows and columns indexed 1 through n, with an `x` in `(i, j)` if `module_i` transitively imports `module_j`, but makes no direct use of the declarations there.

(This is often an indication that some *intermediate* file `module_k` could be split into two parts, one that needs `module_j`, and another that is needed by `module_i`, thereby removing the transitive import of `module_j` into `module_i`.)

The tool further identifies large rectangles of `x`s in this table, and suggests `lake exe graph` commands that can show the dependency structure from the unused import up to the earliest file which "unnecessarily" transitively imports it.

`scripts/unused_in_pole.sh module` (or no argument for all of Mathlib), will calculate the current longest pole in Mathlib (note for this you need to be on a commit on which the speed center has run), and then feed that list of modules into `lake exe unused`.  

Demo video at https://youtu.be/PVj_FHGwhUI

- [x] depends on #18157

nodes.body:
### PR summary [410fe9b3ff](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18156/commits/410fe9b3ff617e0512d408c10deb02c61eb7775f)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Rectangle`
`+ area`
`+ countDecls`
`+ expansions`
`+ height`
`+ instLE`
`+ instPointMembership`
`+ instance (r : Rectangle) (xs : List (Nat × Nat)) : Decidable (r ∈ xs) := by`
`+ instance (x : Nat × Nat) (r : Rectangle) : Decidable (x ∈ r) := by`
`+ instance : DecidableRel ((· : Rectangle) ≤ ·) := by`
`+ instance : Membership Rectangle (List (Nat × Nat))`
`+ instance : ToString Rectangle`
`+ main`
`+ runCmd`
`+ toString`
`+ unused`
`+ unusedImportsCLI`
`+ weightedArea`
`+ width`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Yes, the `lake exe graph` commands only depend on the bottom right corner of the rectangles it finds.

The width of the rectangle tell you how many grey nodes will follow the `--from` node.

The height of the rectangle isn't apparent, but it's "how many steps you could push the `--to` node downwards, with those grey nodes staying grey.

Options:
1. deduplicate the `lake exe graph` commands
2. adjust `lake exe graph` to allow multiple `--to` flags (or passing a list), and then highlight all the `--to` modules some other way.


Option 2 would result in faithfully illustrating the rectangles, but I think it is not really given much extra useful information, and Option 1 is the way to go. :-)
I'm offline for about 48 hours, but I'll try to do the deduplication when I'm back.

Running this on `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Indization.FilteredColimits` shows something interesting: the maximal rectangle starting at a certain point is not unique:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1a8be5c2-f176-4d70-9a20-e174a71f47bd)
As a consequence, the list of returned `graph` invocations contains a duplicate:
```
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Order.Lattice --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Over unused0.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Function.Basic --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Over unused1.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Order.Lattice --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Shapes.Pullback.Cospan unused2.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Function.Basic --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Shapes.Pullback.Cospan unused3.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Order.Lattice --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Over unused4.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Order.Lattice --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.StructuredArrow unused5.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Function.Basic --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.StructuredArrow unused6.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Function.Basic --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Preserves.Shapes.Pullbacks unused7.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Equiv.Set --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Over unused8.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Equiv.Set --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.StructuredArrow unused9.pdf
```

Thanks! I would approve the drive-by fixes to `FormatTable.lean` and `Lint.lean` already. Feel free to extract these into a separate PR (and ask me for review, or `maintainer merge` on my behalf).

I did not look at the meta code in `Unused` much, but the rest looks good to me.
Thanks for making this tool! Most of my comments ask for documentation or suggest simple cleanup.

Running this on `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Indization.FilteredColimits` shows something interesting: the maximal rectangle starting at a certain point is not unique:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1a8be5c2-f176-4d70-9a20-e174a71f47bd)
As a consequence, the list of returned `graph` invocations contains a duplicate:
```
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Order.Lattice --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Over unused0.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Function.Basic --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Over unused1.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Order.Lattice --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Shapes.Pullback.Cospan unused2.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Function.Basic --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Shapes.Pullback.Cospan unused3.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Order.Lattice --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Over unused4.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Order.Lattice --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.StructuredArrow unused5.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Function.Basic --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.StructuredArrow unused6.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Function.Basic --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Preserves.Shapes.Pullbacks unused7.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Equiv.Set --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Over unused8.pdf
lake exe graph --from Mathlib.Logic.Equiv.Set --to Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.StructuredArrow unused9.pdf
```
Thanks for making this tool! Most of my comments ask for documentation or suggest simple cleanup.

Thanks! I would approve the drive-by fixes to `FormatTable.lean` and `Lint.lean` already. Feel free to extract these into a separate PR (and ask me for review, or `maintainer merge` on my behalf).

I did not look at the meta code in `Unused` much, but the rest looks good to me.
not exactly relevant to this PR itself, but it seems that `|` (bar) characters don't get escaped when making a table
please add some sort of docstring for this script. preferably include examples of usage, and list expected parameters.
could you add a docstring?
please add a docstring
since it's a bit subtle why `r.top` and `r.right - 1` *are* the correct choices here (and not off-by-one errors), maybe add a comment explaining what these indices represent?
`10` is a 'magic' constant. Should this be an optional argument?
`"unused.md"` is a 'magic' constant. Should this be an optional argument? (if so, don't forget to also update the message in the line above this one)
could you add to the documentation the fact that the command puts the resulting table in `unused.md` by default?

```suggestion
```
this declaration doesn't get used

```suggestion
open Lean
```
this doesn't get used.
i see you copied the the initial contents from LongestPole/main.lean ... please update the module docs

```suggestion
import Batteries.Data.List.Basic
import Cli.Basic
import ImportGraph.Imports
import LongestPole.Rectangles
import Mathlib.Util.FormatTable
```
above imports suggested by `#min_imports`. feel free to disregard, if minimising imports in these kinds of files isn't necessary.

```suggestion
/--
A rectangle `r` is a product of the left-closed, right-open intervals `[r.left, r.right) × [r.bottom, r.top)`,
whose corners are indexed by natural numbers.
-/
structure Rectangle where
```
I could alternatively use a product of `Ico`s, but I presume you considered this already.
Another option: use the integers for indexing; this would simplify some checks here (but presumably at the expense of other checks in `Unused`.

How about adding a docstring?
```suggestion
/--
We say `r₁ ≤ r₂` if and only if every point in `r₁` is contained in `r₂`.
-/
instance instLE : LE Rectangle where

```suggestion
/--
The number of points in `r`, weighted by the function `w`.
-/

```suggestion
/--
Given a rectangle `r`, return the up to four four rectangles obtained from `r` by
- shifting the bottom left corner one coordinate to the left resp. bottom (if possible), or
- shifting the top right corner one coordinate to the right resp. top.
-/
If you want to prove a lemma: `r` is contained in each of its expansions.

Let's add a comment, how about this?
```
/-- Find all (inclusion-)maximal rectangles contained within `xs`. -/

```suggestion
      | [] => go (r :: maximal) rs

pullRequest.title: feat: lake exe unused
